terms.fullName: Batting Average on Balls In Play
terms.definition: Measures how often a ball in play goes for a hit.
terms.example: A player with a .400 BABIP is likely experiencing good luck and may regress.

terms.definition: Average number of earned runs a pitcher allows per nine innings.
terms.example: An ERA under 3.00 is considered excellent.

terms.definition: Combines offensive events using run-value weights to measure overall batting quality.
terms.example: League average wOBA is roughly .320.

terms.definition: Share of at-bats resulting in a hit.
terms.example: A .300 AVG indicates 3 hits per 10 at-bats.

terms.definition: How often a batter reaches base.
terms.example: .360 OBP is above league average.

terms.definition: Average total bases per at-bat.
terms.example: .500 SLG suggests strong power.

terms.definition: Simple combo of OBP and SLG to summarize production.
terms.example: .800 OPS is good; .900+ is elite.

terms.definition: Power-only measure, stripping out singles.
terms.example: .200 ISO indicates above-average power.

terms.definition: Park- and league-adjusted run creation index (100 = league average).
terms.example: 120 wRC+ means 20% better than league average.

terms.definition: Estimated runs a hitter contributes based on wOBA and context.
terms.example: Higher wRC indicates more total offensive value.

terms.definition: OPS adjusted for park and league (100 = average).
terms.example: An OPS+ of 140 is 40% better than league average.

terms.definition: Percentage of plate appearances ending in strikeout.
terms.example: A 30% K% is high swing-and-miss.

terms.definition: Percentage of plate appearances ending in a walk.
terms.example: A 12% BB% indicates strong plate discipline.

terms.definition: Share of pitches on which the batter swings and misses.
terms.example: Lower SwStr% correlates with better contact skills.

terms.definition: Percentage of batted balls hit 95+ mph.
terms.example: 45% HardHit% suggests consistent quality contact.

terms.definition: Share of batted balls with ideal exit velocity/launch angle for damage.
terms.example: 10% Barrel% is very strong.

terms.definition: Average speed (mph) of a player's batted balls.
terms.example: 92 mph EV implies above-average pop.

terms.definition: Average vertical angle of batted balls.
terms.example: 12–15° LA often yields more extra-base hits.

terms.definition: Share of batted balls hit on the ground.
terms.example: High GB% can suppress home runs.

terms.definition: Share of batted balls hit in the air (fly balls).
terms.example: Higher FB% can boost HR potential.

terms.definition: Share of batted balls classified as line drives.
terms.example: Line drives have the highest hit probability.

terms.definition: Percentage of fly balls that become home runs.
terms.example: Unusually high HR/FB can regress.

terms.definition: Share of batted balls hit to the pull side.
terms.example: Pull-heavy hitters may be shift-vulnerable (rules permitting).

terms.definition: Share of batted balls hit to the opposite field.
terms.example: High Oppo% can indicate all-fields approach.

terms.fullName: Walks plus Hits per Inning Pitched
terms.definition: Base runners allowed per inning.
terms.example: 1.10 WHIP is excellent.

terms.definition: Estimates pitcher performance using HR, BB, HBP, and K, independent of defense.
terms.example: FIP can better predict future ERA than past ERA alone.

terms.definition: Normalizes home run rate by using league-average HR/FB.
terms.example: If HR/FB was fluky, xFIP may differ from FIP.

terms.definition: Advanced estimator of a pitcher's ERA using strikeouts, walks, and batted-ball mix.
terms.example: Often a strong predictor of future run prevention.

terms.definition: Strikeouts scaled to nine innings.
terms.example: 10.0 K/9 shows swing-and-miss stuff.

terms.definition: Walks scaled to nine innings.
terms.example: Under 2.0 BB/9 indicates strong command.

terms.definition: Plate-discipline dominance metric.
terms.example: 15%+ is solid; 20%+ is excellent.

terms.definition: Share of pitches resulting in called strikes or swinging strikes.
terms.example: 30%+ CSW% is strong.

terms.definition: Model-based expected runs allowed using contact quality and strikeouts/walks.
terms.example: xERA below ERA can hint at positive regression.

terms.definition: Share of base runners a pitcher strands.
terms.example: Extreme LOB% often regresses toward league norms.

terms.definition: Home runs allowed scaled to nine innings.
terms.example: Keeping HR/9 low is critical in hitter-friendly parks.

terms.definition: Index of pitch quality using velocity, movement, and release; 100 = average.
terms.example: 120 Stuff+ indicates well above-average raw stuff.

terms.definition: Revolutions per minute (rpm) of a pitch impacting movement and shape.
terms.example: High-spin four-seamers can play well up in the zone.

terms.definition: How often a pitcher gets ahead 0–1.
terms.example: Higher first-pitch strike% often correlates with lower walks.

terms.definition: Share of pitches thrown in the strike zone.
terms.example: Combining Zone% with chase rate (O-Swing%) informs command vs. deception.

terms.definition: Percentage of swings at pitches outside the zone.
terms.example: High O-Swing% shows a pitcher induces chase.

terms.definition: Runs saved above/below average on defense.
terms.example: +10 DRS indicates strong defensive value.

terms.definition: Runs saved using batted-ball location and difficulty.
terms.example: High UZR reflects range and sure-handedness.

terms.definition: Statcast-based estimate of outs saved above average.
terms.example: +8 OAA marks very good fielding.

terms.definition: Runs a catcher adds via receiving and framing borderline pitches.
terms.example: Elite framers can add multiple runs over a season.

terms.definition: Runs gained via throwing out runners or deterring advances.
terms.example: Strong arms increase ARM and reduce extra bases.

terms.definition: Success rate on steal attempts.
terms.example: 75%+ is generally break-even or better.

terms.definition: Total baserunning value (steals, advancement, outs).
terms.example: +3 BsR means ~3 runs added on the bases.

terms.definition: All-in-one value vs. a replacement player; scale varies by source.
terms.example: 5+ WAR ≈ All-Star-level season.

terms.definition: Change in win probability credited to a player’s events.
terms.example: Clutch hits late can spike WPA.

terms.definition: Measures pressure of a game situation (1.0 = average).
terms.example: Closers often pitch in LI > 1.5 spots.

terms.definition: Runs scored minus runs allowed; proxy for team strength.
terms.example: +100 run differential typically correlates with strong records.

terms.definition: Expected winning percentage from runs scored/allowed.
terms.example: Used to spot teams over/underperforming record.

terms.definition: Runs above/below average across the 24 base/out states.
terms.example: Captures value of sequencing and situational hitting.

terms.definition: Bet on which team wins the game straight up.
terms.example: -150 favorite implies ~60% implied probability.

terms.definition: Baseball’s spread, typically ±1.5 runs.
terms.example: +1.5 underdog must lose by ≤1 or win.

terms.definition: Bet on combined runs scored by both teams.
terms.example: Over 8.5 cashes if 9+ total runs are scored.

terms.definition: Bookmaker’s commission embedded in odds.
terms.example: -110 sides imply ~4.5% hold if lines are balanced.

terms.definition: Probability implied by the odds.
Odds shown as +/- values vs. $100 baseline.
terms.example: +200 returns $200 profit on $100 stake.

terms.definition: Total return per $1 stake.
terms.example: 1.80 returns $1.80 total on $1 stake.

terms.definition: Profit : Stake ratio.
terms.example: 5/2 returns $5 profit per $2 stake.

terms.definition: Combines multiple legs; all must win for payout.
terms.example: 3-leg moneyline parlay increases payout and variance.

terms.definition: Creates multiple smaller parlays from a list of selections.
terms.example: A 3-team RR builds three 2-leg parlays.

terms.definition: Wagers on player/team events (e.g., strikeouts, hits).
terms.example: Over 6.5 strikeouts for a starting pitcher.

terms.definition: Season-long outcomes (e.g., World Series winner).
terms.example: Team to win division at +350.

terms.definition: Wagering while the game is in progress.
terms.example: Take the over after a low-scoring first inning at a better number.

terms.definition: Difference between your bet’s odds and the market’s closing odds.
terms.example: Betting Over 8.0 that closes 8.5 shows positive CLV.

terms.definition: Average profit/loss of a bet over many trials.
terms.example: A +EV edge exists when true probability exceeds implied probability.

terms.definition: Bankroll staking formula maximizing long-term growth.
terms.example: Bet fraction = (bp - q)/b for decimal odds b with win prob p.

terms.definition: Sizing bets to reduce risk of ruin.
terms.example: Flat 1–2% unit sizing is common.

terms.definition: Holding positions on both sides at different numbers to win both if final lands in between.
terms.example: Under 9.5 early and Over 8.0 late creates a middle at 9.

terms.definition: Taking an opposing bet to reduce variance or lock profits.
terms.example: Hedge a longshot future after team reaches the finals.

terms.definition: Ensemble of decision trees averaging predictions to reduce variance.
terms.example: Used to predict runs scored using many correlated features.

terms.definition: Gradient-boosted trees optimized for speed and regularization.
terms.example: Commonly outperforms single models on tabular sports data.

terms.definition: Step size for boosting updates; lower often needs more trees.
terms.example: eta = 0.05 with 2000 estimators.

terms.definition: Controls interaction complexity and overfitting.
terms.example: Depth 6–8 is a common starting range.

terms.definition: Total boosting iterations or forest trees.
terms.example: 500 trees with early stopping on validation loss.

terms.definition: Resampling method to estimate out-of-sample performance.
terms.example: K-fold CV with time-aware splits for season data.

terms.definition: Partition data to assess generalization.
terms.example: Train on past seasons, test on current season.

terms.definition: Sequential folds that respect temporal ordering.
terms.example: Walk-forward validation for daily MLB games.

terms.definition: Average absolute difference between predictions and targets.
terms.example: MAE of 0.65 runs on total-runs prediction.

terms.definition: Average squared error; penalizes large misses.
terms.example: Used for hyperparameter tuning alongside MAE.

terms.definition: Square root of MSE; error in original units.
terms.example: RMSE of 0.85 runs is easier to interpret than MSE.

terms.definition: Share of variance explained by the model.
terms.example: R² of 0.25 is typical for noisy sports outcomes.

terms.definition: Creating informative predictors from raw data.
terms.example: Rolling 14-day wOBA or park-adjusted metrics.

terms.definition: Using future or label-derived info in training features.
terms.example: Including final score in a pregame model is leakage.

terms.definition: Penalties to reduce overfitting by shrinking weights.
terms.example: XGBoost’s lambda and alpha terms.

terms.definition: Stop training when validation metric stops improving.
terms.example: Patience of 100 rounds on eval_set.

terms.definition: Exhaustive search over specified parameter grids.
terms.example: Try depths {4,6,8} × learning rates {0.03,0.1}.

terms.definition: Sample parameter combinations randomly for efficiency.
terms.example: Use distributions for max_depth and min_child_weight.

terms.definition: Relative contribution of features to model predictions.
terms.example: Gain-based importances highlight impactful stats.

terms.definition: Game-theory method to attribute prediction contributions.
terms.example: Explains why a game total was projected high.

terms.definition: Chained steps for preprocessing and modeling.
terms.example: Scale → encode → model with cross-validation.

terms.definition: Simple benchmark to beat before complex models.
terms.example: Predict league-average runs adjusted for park.

terms.definition: Process of ingesting and preparing data for analytics.
terms.example: Pull from stats APIs, clean, and load to PostgreSQL.

terms.definition: Interface for programmatically requesting data or actions.
terms.example: statsapi.mlb.com endpoints for schedules and stats.

terms.definition: Restrictions on request frequency.
terms.example: Throttle calls to theoddsapi.com to avoid 429 errors.

terms.definition: Relational database used for storing structured data.
terms.example: Games, markets, and features stored in normalized tables.
